statement.text: While NPV is the theoretically preferred capital budgeting method, it has important limitations and assumptions that practitioners must understand. These include assumptions about certain cash flows, fixed discount rates, and the inability to capture managerial flexibility. Understanding these limitations leads to more sophisticated approaches like real options analysis.

explanation.intuition: NPV tells you the value assuming you make the investment and let it play out. But in reality, you can adjust course - expand if things go well, abandon if they don't. Standard NPV misses this 'option value' of managerial flexibility.
explanation.key_insight: NPV's key limitation is treating investment as a now-or-never, all-or-nothing decision with known outcomes. In reality: (1) many decisions can be deferred, (2) projects can be expanded, contracted, or abandoned mid-course, (3) cash flows are uncertain, and (4) discount rates change. These limitations lead to real options theory and Monte Carlo simulation.
explanation.technical_details: Specific assumptions and limitations: (1) Cash flow certainty - NPV uses expected values, ignoring variance, (2) Constant discount rate - assumes flat term structure and unchanging risk, (3) No managerial flexibility - ignores option to expand/contract/abandon, (4) Perfect capital markets - unlimited borrowing at WACC, (5) Reinvestment assumption - cash flows reinvested at discount rate, (6) Independent projects - doesn't capture portfolio effects or synergies.

cash_flow_uncertainty.issue: NPV uses point estimates of cash flows
cash_flow_uncertainty.consequence: Same NPV could result from low-risk or high-risk projects

single_discount_rate.issue: Uses constant rate regardless of cash flow timing or risk changes
single_discount_rate.consequence: Misprices projects with changing risk profiles

estimation_errors.issue: Garbage in, garbage out - relies on accurate forecasts
estimation_errors.consequence: Optimism bias leads to overestimated NPVs

ignores_strategic_value.issue: Doesn't capture strategic positioning or learning
ignores_strategic_value.consequence: May reject platform investments that enable future opportunities

definitions_glossary.real_options: The right but not obligation to make future investments, captured through options pricing
definitions_glossary.monte_carlo_simulation: Technique using random sampling to model uncertainty in cash flows
definitions_glossary.optimism_bias: Systematic tendency to overestimate project benefits and underestimate costs

learning_objectives: Identify key assumptions underlying NPV analysis
Recognize situations where standard NPV may fail
Understand when alternative methods may be needed
pedagogical.prerequisites_description: Solid understanding of NPV, DCF analysis, basic statistics
practice_problems: A pharmaceutical R&D project has low expected NPV but huge upside if successful. Is NPV the right tool?
When should you use real options instead of NPV?
How can sensitivity analysis help address NPV limitations?

skos:definition: An analysis of the key assumptions, limitations, and potential failures of standard Net Present Value analysis, with solutions for more sophisticated valuation.
